--- title: "Day 11" title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: images/lake.jpg data-background-size: contain data-background-opacity: "0.5" subtitle: "Math 216: Statistical Thinking" author: "Bastola" format: revealjs: html-math-method: mathjax mathjax-url: "https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mathjax/3.2.2/MathJax.js" theme: [default, scss/main.scss] slide-number: true preview-links: auto history: true chalkboard: src: drawings.json transition: slide background-transition: fade touch: false controls: true --- ## Introduction to Continuous Probability Distribution {.font80} ::: cle10 ::: font80 - A **continuous random variable**, $x$, can take any value within a specified range. It is graphically depicted by a smooth curve known as the **Probability Density Function (PDF)**, $f(x)$. - **Key Concepts of PDF**: - **Probability of an Interval**: The area under the curve between any two points $a$ and $b$ ($a \leq x \leq b$) represents the probability of $x$ falling within that range. - **Non-negativity**: $f(x)\geq0$ for all $x$. - **Total Probability**: The integral of $f(x)$ across its entire range equals 1, representing the total set of outcomes for $x$. - **Endpoint Consideration**: Including endpoints in an interval, like $x=a$ or $x=b$, does not change the computed probability since $P(x=a)=0$ for any particular $a$. ::: ::: ## Properties and Visualization of Continuous Distributions {.font70} ::: row ::: left ![](images/continuous_pdf.png) ::: ::: right ::: font80 ::: cle6 **Function Representation**: $f(x)$ is often referred to as a density function or frequency function. **Calculating Probabilities**: The probability that $x$ will fall between any two specific values, $a$ and $b$, is given by the area under $f(x)$ between these points. **Graphical Illustration**: The shape of the distribution varies based on the data it models, reflecting different types of continuous random variables. **Zero Probability at a Point**: A fundamental property of continuous variables: The probability of $x$ assuming any exact value, such as $a$, is zero, reinforcing that continuous variables span ranges rather than discrete points. ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Introduction to Uniform Distribution ::: {.callout-note title="Definition"} Uniform distribution, or rectangular distribution, is a type of continuous probability distribution where every outcome in a specified range is equally likely. - **Graphical Representation**: Depicted as a rectangle because the probability density function is constant within the bounds. - **Basic Formula**: The probability density function (PDF) is $f(x) = \frac{1}{b-a}$ for $x$ within the interval $[a, b]$. ::: ## Visualizing and Calculating Probabilities {.font80} ::: row ::: left ![](images/uniform_pdf.png) ::: ::: right ::: cle11 ::: font90 - **Area Calculation**: Probabilities are calculated as the area under the PDF curve, simplifying to the width of the interval times the height of the PDF. - **Example**: For an interval $[a, b]$, the probability that $x$ falls within $[c, d]$ (where $c$ and $d$ are within $a$ and $b$) is $(d-c) \times \frac{1}{b-a}$. ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Statistical Measures
::: font80 ::: cle13 - **Mean and Median**: The mean, $\mu$, and median of a uniform distribution are the same, given by $\mu = \frac{c+d}{2}$. - **Variance**: The variance, $\sigma^2$, is calculated as $\sigma = \frac{(d-c)^2}{12}$. ::: ::: ## Real-World Applications
::: font80 ::: cle15 - **Uniformity**: Ideal for modelling scenarios where each outcome within a range is equally likely, such as random draws from a finite set or simulation inputs. - **Examples**: Used in simulations, randomized algorithms, and systems modeling where equal likelihood is assumed for inputs or scenarios within a certain range. ::: ::: ## ::: font60 > Example 1: Example 1 An unprincipled used-car dealer sells a car to an unsuspecting buyer, even though the dealer knows that the car will have a major breakdown within the next 6 months. The dealer provides a warranty of 45 days on all cars sold. Let $x$ represent the length of time until the breakdown occurs. Assume that x is a uniform random variable with values between 0 and 6 months. a. Calculate and interpret the mean and standard deviation of $X$. ::: ## ::: font60 b. Graph the probability distribution of $X$ , and show the mean on the horizontal axis. Also show oneand two-standard-deviation intervals around the mean. ::: custom-space ::: c. Calculate the probability that the breakdown occurs while the car is still under warranty. :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
